<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 177, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/52  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 411, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Planning, Analysis and Evaluation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 806, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 30.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
1 Fig. 1.1 shows two identical cylindrical metal conductors \(P\) and \(Q\), each of length \(L\) and cross-sectional area \(A\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[163, 116, 838, 312]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 331, 532, 348]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 363, 918, 395]]<|/det|>
The conductors are placed parallel to each other. The perpendicular distance from the midpoint of P to point X is \(p\). The perpendicular distance from the midpoint of Q to point X is \(q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 409, 918, 457]]<|/det|>
The two conductors are electrically connected in parallel. This parallel combination is connected in series to a power supply and a resistor. The potential difference \(V\) between the ends of P is the same as the potential difference between the ends of Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 471, 715, 488]]<|/det|>
The magnetic flux density at X due to the currents in the conductors is \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 501, 567, 518]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(B\) is related to \(p\) by the relationship

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[426, 521, 576, 555]]<|/det|>
\[
B=\frac{Y A V}{L p}+\frac{Y Z A V}{L q}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 564, 364, 579]]<|/det|>
where Y and \(Z\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 594, 693, 611]]<|/det|>
Plan a laboratory experiment to test the relationship between \(B\) and \(p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 625, 625, 642]]<|/det|>
Draw a diagram showing the arrangement of your equipment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 655, 700, 672]]<|/det|>
Explain how the results could be used to determine values for Y and Z.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 686, 383, 702]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should include:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 717, 393, 733]]<|/det|>
- the procedure to be followed

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 747, 410, 763]]<|/det|>
- the measurements to be taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 778, 348, 794]]<|/det|>
- the control of variables

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 809, 351, 825]]<|/det|>
- the analysis of the data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 840, 447, 856]]<|/det|>
- any safety precautions to be taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 581, 91]]<|/det|>
2 A student investigates the cooling of a liquid in a beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 707, 121]]<|/det|>
The temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the laboratory is measured using a thermometer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 643, 152]]<|/det|>
Hot water is added to an insulated beaker, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 161, 752, 408]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 421, 532, 438]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 453, 918, 484]]<|/det|>
The thermometer measures the temperature of the water. At time \(t\) the temperature of the water is \(\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 498, 454, 515]]<|/det|>
A series of readings of \(t\) and \(\theta\) are taken.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 530, 564, 547]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that \(\theta\) and \(t\) are related by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 559, 593, 584]]<|/det|>
\[
\theta=\theta_{\mathrm{R}}+\left(\theta_{0}-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right) \mathrm{e}^{-\left(\frac{t}{k}\right)}
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 596, 578, 613]]<|/det|>
where \(\theta_{0}\) is the temperature at \(t=0\) and \(K\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 628, 144, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 626, 707, 645]]<|/det|>
(a) A graph is plotted of \(\ln \left(\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\right)\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(t\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 657, 611, 674]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions for the gradient and \(y\)-intercept.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 841, 912, 858]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
\begin{array}{r}
\text { gradient }= \\
y \text {-intercept }=
\end{array}
\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 484, 91]]<|/det|> (b) Values of \(t\) and \(\theta\) are given in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 104, 541, 120]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 135, 855, 448]]<|/det|>
\(t / \min\)\(\theta /^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)\((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{C}\)\(\ln \left((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{C}\right)\)
6.0\(75.0 \pm 0.5\)
12.0\(64.5 \pm 0.5\)
18.0\(57.0 \pm 0.5\)
24.0\(50.0 \pm 0.5\)
30.0\(44.5 \pm 0.5\)
36.0\(41.0 \pm 0.5\)
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 459, 435, 476]]<|/det|> The value of \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) is \((18.5 \pm 0.5)^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 489, 775, 507]]<|/det|> Calculate and record values of \((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{C}\) and \(\ln \left((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{C}\right)\) in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 503, 692, 521]]<|/det|> Include the absolute uncertainties in \((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})\) and \(\ln \left((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{C}\right)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 536, 144, 553]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 536, 185, 553]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 535, 880, 553]]<|/det|> (i) Plot a graph of \(\ln \left((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{C}\right)\) against \(t / \min\). Include error bars for \(\ln \left((\theta-\theta_{\mathrm{R}})^{\prime \prime} \mathrm{C}\right)\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 188, 584]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 566, 920, 599]]<|/det|> (ii) Draw the straight line of best fit and a worst acceptable straight line on your graph. Label both lines. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 613, 191, 630]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 612, 920, 644]]<|/det|> (iii) Determine the gradient of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 75, 185, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(iv) Determine the \(y\)-intercept of the line of best fit. Include the absolute uncertainty in your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 228, 587, 247]]<|/det|>
<form>\(
y-\text {intercept}=
\)
